nodePath - - The label of the tree node to find where nested nodes are separated with forward slashes

findFirstWidget

protected <T extends Widget> T findFirstWidget(Widget parentWidget,
                                               java.lang.Class<T> widgetClass)
Find a widget by a recursive, breadth-first, search of the given widget's children. This method should only be used when a Window Tester Widget Locator bug exists and all possible Window Tester location strategies have been exhausted.

IMPORTANT! - This method must be called from the UI thread. Ex: Display.getDefault().syncExec(new Runnable() { findWidget() }); Whenever a helper must use the UI thread, that operation is called an 'atomic operation.' Every atomic operation *must* be called between a pair of IUIContext.handleConditions() calls. Example:
ui.handleConditions(); Display.getDefault().syncExec(new Runnable() { findWidget() }); ui.handleConditions();
Without these calls conditions handlers are not run and unexpected UI states (unexpected dialogs, for example) will cause the test run to hang.

Parameters:
parentWidget - - The parent widget to search. Must not be null
widgetClass - - The class of the Widget to find
Returns:
the widget - The first instance of a Widget of the given type or null if no Widget is found

findUniqueElement

protected <T> T findUniqueElement(java.util.List<T> before,

Returns:
T - Find the unique element in the before and after lists

handleConditions

protected void handleConditions(IUIContext ui)
Whenever the state of the workbench changes at the API level, this method must be called prior to that call. The reason is that the state of the workbench can be changed through the API in a way that is otherwise impossible through the UI (for example, making a modal shell's parent the active window).

If you're not 100% sure that you need to be calling this method, then you shouldn't be calling this method.

isLinux

protected boolean isLinux()
You probably shouldn't be calling this. OS-Specific workarounds are a last-ditch thing

public void listenForDialog(IUIContext ui,

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI generated input
handler - - How to react to the shell
condition - - How to tell if the given handler applies to a popped shell

setExpectedDelay

protected void setExpectedDelay(IUIContext ui,
                                long millis)
setExpectedDelay - For certain operations that may cause a long running busy cursor (keeping the UI thread from responding) all test harness safety nets need to be notified that an operation will take a long time. The default for the UI thread safety nets is 2 minutes. An example usage is the upgrade dialog where the test thread waits on a condition until the upgrade is complete (upgrades can take much longer than 2 minutes)

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI generated input
millis - - The number of milliseconds that the UI thread safety nets should expect to wait before failing the test. In other words, if the test is still waiting on a single operation after this many millis then fail the test.

stopListeningForAllDialogs

public void stopListeningForAllDialogs(IUIContext ui)
Stop listening for all unexpected dialogs. This is the complimentary method to the listenForDialog method

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI input

stopListeningForDialog

public void stopListeningForDialog(IUIContext ui,
                                   IWorkbenchShellHandler handler)
stopListeningForDialog - Stop listening for the given dialog.

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI generated input
handler - - The shell handler that should no longer be handled through the Shell Monitor. Should have been registered through the listenForDialog method

toShell

protected int[] toShell(IUIContext ui,
                        Control control)
Utility to calculate the given component's x,y coordinates relative to the first parent shell on the widget's hierarchy.

Returns:
int[] - int[0] = x coordinate; int[1] = y coordinate

waitForControl

public static <T extends Control> T waitForControl(IUIContext ui,
                                                   IWidgetLocator controlLocator,
                                                   java.lang.Class<T> controlClass)
Wait for a control to be found. Do not assume a failure if the control is not immediately found (do not close open dialogs, do not take a screenshot, etc). If the control is not found after 30 seconds, THEN close all dialogs, take a screenshot, fail the test, etc

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI generated input
controlLocator - - How to find the control
controlClass - - The widget class to find

waitForControlEnabled

public static <T extends Control> T waitForControlEnabled(IUIContext ui,
                                                          IWidgetLocator controlLocator,
                                                          java.lang.Class<T> controlClass)
waitForControlEnabled - Wait for the control registered to the given key can be found and is enabled. Do not fail the test if the control is not immediately found

Parameters:
ui - - Driver for UI generated input
controlLocator - - How to find the control
controlClass - - The control class to find
Returns:
T - The control instance found
